start: ^Many generations ago, the world outside the bounds of the City ended, but the City did not know that. It kept assembling and disassembling itself forever, trapping you and your tribe inside.
^The City is alive, and to many - including many in your tribe - the City is God, who provides, but also punishes those who do not follow His will.
^You are the Chieftain of your tribe, and it is your responsibility to see to the well-being of your people, and to lead them in your never-ending pilgrimage through the City, ever Windward.
^You look upon them now, once more gathering their belongings to continue your trek, even as the Wind picks up.
^Your warriors stand proud, front and center, always ready to defend their fellow tribesmen. (+Warriors) (+Warchief)
^A populous tribe is yours, and skilled too in many things: the trades, claywork, leatherwork, herdwork. (+Tribesmen) (+Clayworker)
^It is a sad sight. Once you were mighty, but the years have taken their toll. (+Difficulty)

g-0: ^It is time to decide where you are headed next. But a good chieftain does not make decisions without consulting their advisors. As always, you look to...

c-3: ^Knowing the City and its moods and secrets is the purvey of the Shaman. Reading the Wind, communing with the eidolons of the City, and remembering the history of the tribe; all these things the Shamans do, and you have learned to listen to their advice.
c-4: ^Although the Shamans think they can read the City's intentions by listening to the Wind, your Scouts can tell you what they saw with their own two eyes. You have always trusted more in what you can see and touch than the secretive world of the eidolons the Shamans commune with.
c-5: ^Without your warriors, your tribesmen would be at the mercy of the City - or rather its inhabitants. They are what stands between you and the predations of outcasts, scavengers and tribeless raiders - not to mention the monsters of the City itself.

g-1: ^However, you already know what they will advise you to do. Last night, you saw the Hunter-Killers swarm an area just Windward of you. You heard the patter of their weapons echoing off the buildings, and then silence. Whatever they hunted, and killed, would be there. It could also be an unfortunate fellow tribe that caught the ire of the City for some reason, but usually when the Hunter-Killers are found this far from the Veil, it is because of an intrusion.

^From time to time, things trickle in from beyond the Veil; things the Disassemblers missed, or ignored. That was what happened to your tribe, many generations ago, although in most cases it is not living things, but objects. But the interest of the Hunter-Killers suggest something that was alive. You consider your own motivations for going.
^Information about the world beyond the Veil is a valuable commodity when trading with other tribes. (+Pactmaker)
^You must always learn more of how the City works, and thinks. Your survival depends on it. (+Shaman)
^Legend says, some Intruders in the past brought with them wondrous weapons. The tribe could use such artefacts. (+Warchief)
^Your curiosity must be sated, that is all. (+Trickster)
g-2: ^The tribe is all but ready to head out. As chieftain, you know the content of every pack and cart. How much surplus food you have. How much unmoulded Clay remains to fashion into tools when necessary. But beyond that, you also know the heart of your people: you know when their hearts are strong and when they falter.
^You observe your herd of rustled cattle with pride. Their former brands are all but healed. (+Food)(+Trickster)
^The clayworkers' carts are laden heavy. The City has been kind to you. (+Clay)(+Clayworker)
^You can hear the laughter in the air, see the trust in their eyes as they look upon you. (+Courage)(+Pactmaker)
^Alas, there is little to be proud of now. Your herd is thin, your supplies running out. And it shows. (+Difficulty)
g-3: ^Even as you prepare to give the order to move, you think back to what your
^, Chieftain before you, always told you.
^"Remember: most things can be solved by words, not blood." (+Pactmaker)
^"Be like the Clay we use for our tools: always ready to change." (+Clayworker)
^"Listen to the City and learn its language, and all doors will open for you." (+Shaman)
g-4: ^You tell your people to start moving. Soon, the caravan of your tribe begins walking down the cracked and dusty pavement, between the looming half-built houses of the City, towards your destiny.

touch_edge: ^You are sucked up into the void and die, oh no.
endDemo: ^<color=red>This is the end of the demo! More to come soon! Thanks for playing!</color>

b: ^Text for the -very first- time you visit.
^Text that comes if the location was created over 5 days ago.
^Text that shows if the location is very close to the edge. Use together with creation time to check if the reason is because it was newly created or because it is about to be destroyed.

c-0: ^Start a timer with a start time of 0 and an end time of 5, that goes to the stitch timeEnded when finished.

timeEnded: ^This is the stitch we go to once the timer ends. Let's reward the player!

intro_battlefield: ^You survey the battlefield and its scars. One thing is certain: the Disassemblers will not leave anything they find here intact. If you wish to scavenge anything else, now is the time to do it.

b: ^The formidable steel bird lies dormant, although you curiously enough find no damage on it aside from what it suffered when it crashed. Finding an intact one is quite rare. You personally open up its cerebral carapace and remove the little nugget of Clay that was its mind before you let your Clayworkerks loose on it.
^Soon enough, you have amassed a nice little pile of Clay, ready to be repurposed.

^You watch your Clayworkers pry at the machine's steel carapace, when suddenly, with an ominous whirr, the bird stirs. Before anyone has time to react, it twists and turns, razor talons raking open the Clayworkers swarming over it. Your tribesmen scatter as the Hunter-Killer's scorch ray begins to build up, but something is broken in the mechanism, and with a final shudder the bird explodes.
^Nothing useful remains afterwards. Grimly, you gather your dead and wounded.

corpse: ^You carefully make your way across the battlefield, your warriors tense and ready for anything, while your tribesmen stay at a safe distance. The air itself smells burnt, beyond the smoke: evidence of the Hunter-Killers' scorch-rays being used.

^The battle was clearly intense. You see a dead Hunter-Killer wreck, fresh craters, and several crumbled golems. The tableau of destruction all points towards the smoking ruin of a man, lying where the Hunter-Killers left him in the middle of the road. Even at this distance, you can see he is not dressed like a Tribesman.
^How could one man cause such mayhem? You sense the unease from your warriors.
^You are not afraid. Approach the corpse yourself.
^Send a tracker to give you the all-clear.

b: ^Your warriors are encouraged by your bravery, their hesitation forgotten.
^Despite attempting to put on a brave face, your warriors can sense how ill at ease you are.
^At your command, one of your trackers prowls on ahead while the rest of you wait. You are the chieftain, and your safety is more important than theirs.
^The trackers look surprised when you command one of them to move forward. After a brief, whispered discussion, one of them takes the plunge.

c-1: ^You watch as he approaches the corpse, poking at it with his spear. After a few tense moments, the tracker waves at you to approach.
g-0: ^You approach the corpse. Its charred skin is stretched taut over skull and flesh, leaving you with no notion of what the man - or, for that matter, woman - might have looked like. Their clothes, what remains of them, are of strange make, but definitely some type of armor.

^That is when you see it. It lies next to his open palm, catching the light of the sun on its spotless golden skin. You recognize what it is immediately: an ombrascope. You reach for it without stopping to think; a golden ombrascope, held by an outsider, is unheard of.

^The ombrascope fits perfectly in your palm, and feels smooth and warm. By shining a light through its center, one can project glyphs onto surfaces both big and small; glyphs that can open doors, chase away Hunter-Killers, or protect against Disassemblers.

^But this one feels different. You can see the thin filaments that create the intricate shadows move, as if by themselves. Rearranging themselves into new shapes. New glyphs. You have to get this to your Shamans, at once.
^Give the ombrascope to your shamans, while you attend to other matters.

b: ^As you shine a light through the ombrascope, you see not a static glyph, but shifting images. You stare at them, transfixed, as they shift. You notice your shamans have joined you when you try to start making sense of them.
^You try to understand the vague images you can see reflected off the sand, but are soon frustrated. The shamans will be able to interpret them better, you hope.

s0: ^You set up camp in the shadow of a half-built apartment building, using the plastic sheets that cover the sides to reinforce your tents.
s1: ^Your tribesmen contentedly begin settling down, shaking their tired legs.
s2: ^You make camp, like you have done so many times before. The Wind howls as you work in silence.
s3: ^The order to set up camp propagates down your convoy. Mothers lift their children from their backs, sighing with relief.
s4: ^You order your warriors to secure the perimeter as your tribesmen begin erecting the camp tents.
s5: ^Erecting the camp is practiced action; soon, the smell of cooking begins drifting towards you.

s0: ^Your tribesmen get to work and quickly disassemble the camp. Within minutes, it is like you were never there.
s1: ^Your tribesmen set to work pulling down tents and packing the carts. In no time at all, you are ready to go.
s2: ^Once the order is given, it takes mere minutes for the camp to disappear into packs and carts. Soon, your tribe is ready to move again.
s3: ^You give the order and watch as children are coralled, tents pulled down and draught animals hitched to carts. Soon, you are ready to go.
s4: ^Decamping takes mere minutes, your tribesmen working in effective lockstep. Everyone knows speed is of the essence in the City.

s0: ^Your tribesmen, practically sleeping on their feet, collapse into their tents. Only the night watchmen stay awake, peering into the dark by the campfires.
s1: ^Exhausted men,  women and children gratefully crawl into their tents. Within minutes, the only movement in the camp are the night watchmen stirring the flames of the campfires.
s2: ^You can hear sighs of relief throughout your people, as they are finally given a chance to rest. Soon, the whole camp is still.

s0: ^Your tribesmen settle in for the long night by their campfires, singing songs to their children to put them to sleep.
s1: ^Soon, your camp is lit up by multiple campfires, as your tribe prepares for the night.
s2: ^Once the night watch is set up, there is little else to do but tuck in and rest your wearied bones.

s0: ^Your tribesmen, delirous with exhaustion, collapse into their tents. A silence falls over the camp within minutes.
s1: ^Exhausted men,  women and children gratefully crawl into their tents. The guards left outside stare with bleary eyes into the Wind.
s2: ^You can hear sighs of relief throughout your people, as they are finally given a chance to rest. Soon, the whole camp is still.

s0: ^Your tribesmen settle in for a rest from the never-ending walk, happy to rest their legs.
s1: ^No matter the time of day, rest is always welcome. Soon, the camp goes quiet.
s2: ^The camp settles in for a rest, although small groups of those not quite weary enough chat quietly by tent openings.

s0: ^The people crawling from their tents are like new; revived once more after a good rest.
s1: ^You can tell from the atmosphere in the camp that the rest did more than good. Your tribe is once more ready to face the City.
s2: ^Despite some groaning, most seem to have recovered well. Soon, the camp is bustling with energy.
s3: ^After a long rest, your tribesmen seem fully revived.

restDone: ^Your tribe is once again rested and ready to head out.

b:
^There is a sense of reverence as you settle down around the golden ombrascope. The moment you shine a light through it, you can see the image projected through it is no mere glyph: it moves.

^This is something different, and interpreting it will take time.
^You and your shamans huddle around a campfire, the shadows of the ombrascope especially lively from the flickering flames.
^Finding a place where the sun shines through unrestricted, you and your shamans settle down to read what the ombrascope tells you.

discover_hospital: ^Normal ombrascopes display a single glyph, and it is up to the shamans to know what that glyph means. This ombrascope, you find, displays images. Images that slowly morph and change, crystallizing one after the other as the filaments inside the ombrascope shift around. Soon, you find a pattern to them.

c-0: ^The first image is the most glyph-like. Your shamans recognize them as a pattern of streets and buildings. It centres on one building.
c-1: ^The streets coalesce into a series of signage letters and numbers; the address. The shamans insist they can interpret it.
c-2: ^The third image you recognize without help: it resolves into an image of the building itself. It is a cursed place, and all who go near disappear forever.
c-3: ^As you bring it up, the looping three images stop, and change - as if the ombrascope itself is listening to you. What follows is a series of rapidly changing images that make precious little sense. You will need much more time to decipher the 'why' of it.
^Until then, you have a choice to make, as chieftain. But, they warn, you ignore the ombrascope's guidance at your peril.
^The Murmuring House can now be visited on your map.

rationing: ^It is time to declare the day's rations. As always, it is up to you to decide how.
^There isn't enough food for everyone, but you distribute what you have.

c-0: ^You distribute the rations evenly to everyone. No-one goes hungry today.
c-1: ^Your tribe understands food is at a premium. No-one complains, but the mood is slightly less jovial.
c-2: ^The mood is grim as the ration sizes for the day are revealed. The march ahead will be tough.
c-3: ^The announcement is met with quiet shock. Not that anyone was truly surprised, but no-one is happy.
c-4: ^To escape every day from the Veil, to walk endless miles across cracked asphalt, requires energy. To do so on an empty stomach is torture. You will not be able to continue like this for long.
g-0: ^Once the rationing for the day has been declared, the tribe continues.

scavenge: ^ able-bodied tribesmen. What would you like them to look for?

b: ^Your skilled clayworkers head out together with the tribesmen to help them look.
^Your tribesmen will have to tend to themselves and find what they can.
^Your tribesmen begin foraging, safe in the knowledge a warrior is always nearby to defend them if need be.
^You do not have enough warriors to defend everyone. As a result, the area you can forage becomes smaller.
^Your tribe is renowned for its hospitality. You are sure many will be interested.
^Your tribesmen are a surly lot, and you wonder how much new blood they will be able to attract.

scavenge_done_supplies: ^Your tribesmen return with what they find, for your clayworkers to melt down.
scavenge_done_food: ^Your tribesmen return with what they find, growing in cracks or hidden in strange crevices.

b: ^Your tribesmen return with stragglers, eager to join a new tribe.

farming_done: ^Your seedlings grow with monstrous quickness. Once they are ripe, you harvest them quickly, before they grow out of hand.
train: ^All of your tribesmen can take up arms to defend the caravan - but that means they will not be available to scavenge or do other kinds of work. You will also need Clay to fashion into weapons and armour for them, and time to give them the training they need.
^Train a small warband (+5 Warriors, -5 Tribesmen, -5 Clay)
^Train a larger warband (+10 Warriors, -10 Tribesmen, -10 Clay)

b: ^You set an example for the recruits to follow, and the volunteers you get are eager to get started. Training them will be short work.
^You fail to garner much enthusiasm among your people, and the warriors you finally get are slow to learn.
^You set an example for the recruits to follow, and the volunteers you get are eager to get started. Training them will be short work.
^You fail to garner much enthusiasm among your people, and the warriors you finally get are slow to learn.

training_done_small: ^Your new warriors go to join their new comrades, ready to protect the life of their fellow tribesmen.
training_done_big: ^Your new warriors go to join their new comrades, ready to protect the life of their fellow tribesmen.

b: ^You send out your best scouts to find out more about the area you are in. They are soon back with information
^You send out your scouts, but they return with limited information:

^Your tribesmen balk at the idea of coming any closer to the House of Murmurs. Even out here you can hear the unnatural sounds emanating from behind the cracked walls. Whatever magic keeps the Disassemblers from destroying the building has also left it in a terrible state.

hospital: ^As you approach the rusted chain-link fence, it starts to swing open, apparently welcoming you. You step through, but not everyone is quite as brave.
^Encourage your whole tribe to pass through.

b: ^After a bit of hesitation, the rest of your tribe pass through the gate. You hope you made the right call.
^Most pass through, but you notice some who slink away, preferring to abandon the tribe rather than risk this cursed place. You wonder if they might not be the smarter ones.

c-1: ^You tell the rest of your tribe to wait by the gate. They seem grateful to do so. Your warriors, too proud to show fear, follow you in.
c-2: ^You turn around and leave - for now.

insideHospital: ^The second door opens without hands as you approach. It takes you a moment to understand what you are seeing inside. Despite the dirt on the floor and the vines growing up the walls, you realize this building has never been looted.

^Chairs sit where they are supposed to, monitors are placed on tables, couches and chairs line the walls next to flower pots with the dried-out husks of plants in them. As you slowly make your way into the building, you remember the old stories the Shamans used to tell of the world Before.
^That is when you hear the sound. Not a murmur any more - no, a screech. The door to the outside closes behind you with a bang, shutting you in with whatever inhabits this cursed place.

b: ^Your people, all trapped in there with you, look to you for leadership. The door is shut securely. It will not budge.
^Your warriors crowd around you, gripping their weapons. Unsure of if they will be any use.

insideHospital: ^You turn to look in the direction of your shuffling doom - even as you feel something vibrate in pouch you keep the ombrascope in. You touch it, and find that the whole pouch is indeed shaking.
^But you do not have time to think about that. From the darkness steps a monstrosity; a machine of the ancients, oozing from every pore black, living clay.
^"It is time for your examination." It hums merrily, lifting a sawblade.
